case_name: Petitions under Art. 32 of the Constitution

facts.text: Petitions under Article 32 of the Constitution challenge the vires of the Working Journalists Conditions of Service and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1955 (45 of 1955) and the Wage Board decision constituted thereunder.

anchor.surface_text: These petitions under Art. 32 of the Constitution raise the question as to the vires of the Working Journalists  Conditions of Service  and Miscella

facts.text: Newspaper industry in India originally started as individual newspapers founded by leaders but developed into profit-making industry with big industrialists investing and combines controlling several newspapers.

anchor.surface_text: The newspaper industry in India did number originally start as an industry, but started as individual newspapers founded by leaders in the national,

facts.text: Uttar Pradesh Government appointed committee on June 18, 1947 to enquire into conditions of work of newspaper employees.

anchor.surface_text: On June 18, 1947, the Government of Uttar Pradesh appointed a companymittee to enquire into the companyditions of work of the employees of

facts.text: Central Provinces Berar Government appointed Inquiry Committee on March 27, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: On March 27, 1948, the Government of Central Provinces Berar also appointed an Inquiry Committee to examine and report on certain questions

facts.text: Press Commission constituted on September 23, 1952 under Chairmanship of Shri Justice G. S. Rajadhyaksha.

anchor.surface_text: The appointment of the Press companymission was thereafter announced in a Communique issued by the Govt. of India, Ministry of Information

facts.text: Press Commission submitted report on July 14, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The Commission companypleted its enquiry and submitted its report on July 14, 1954.

facts.text: Press Commission found that out of 137 concerns, only 59 returned profits and 68 showed losses, with overall profit of 6 lakhs on 7 crores capital.

anchor.surface_text: Amongst other things it found that out of 137 companycerns about whom information was available only 59 were returning profits and 68

facts.text: Working Journalists Industrial Disputes Act, 1955 (1 of 1955) received assent on March 12, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Almost immediately after the Report of the Press Commission, Parliament passed the Working Journalists  Industrial Disputes  Act, 1955  I of

facts.text: Working Journalists Conditions of Service and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1955 (45 of 1955) received assent on December 20, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The Act as finally passed was entitled The Working Journalists  Conditions of Service  and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1955  45 of 1955

facts.text: Central Government constituted Wage Board on May 2, 1956 under Section 8 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: By a numberification dated May 2, 1956, the Central Government companystituted a Wage Board under s. 8 of the Act for fixing rates of wages

facts.text: Wage Board Chairman: Shri H. V. Divatia, Retired Judge of Bombay High Court.

anchor.surface_text: appointed Shri H. V. Divatia, Retired Judge of the High Court of Judicature, Bombay, as the Chairman of the Board.

facts.text: Wage Board members representing employers: Shri G. Narasimhan, Shri A. R. Bhat, Shri K. P. Kesava Menon.

anchor.surface_text: The three members of the Board who were numberinated to represent employers in relation to newspaper establishments were  1  Shri G. Narasimhan

facts.text: Wage Board members representing working journalists: Shri G. Venkataraman, Shri C. Raghavan, Shri G. N. Acharya.

anchor.surface_text: The other three members of the Board who were numberinated to represent working journalists were  1  Shri G. Venkataraman, M.P.,  2  Shri C. Ragh

facts.text: Shri K. P. Kesava Menon resigned on June 21, 1956; replaced by Shri K. M. Cherian on July 14, 1956.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that Shri K. P. Kesava Menon sent in his resignation on or about June 21, 1956, and by a numberification dated July 14, 1956

facts.text: Wage Board held meetings in various cities: Trivandrum (Sep 7-10, 1956), Madras (Sep 15-20), Delhi (Oct 19-26), Calcutta (Nov 25-Dec 4), Bombay multiple dates up to Apr 24, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Meetings of the Board were held at Trivandrum from September 7, to September 10, 1956, in Madras from September 15, to September 20, 1956

facts.text: Wage Board decisions recorded on April 30, 1957, with employers' minute of dissent.

anchor.surface_text: These decisions were recorded on April 30, 1957, but the representatives of the employers thought fit to append a minute of dissent

facts.text: Wage Board decision published in Gazette of India on May 11, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: The above decision of the Wage Board was published by the Central Government in the Gazette of India Extraordinary dated May 11, 1957.

facts.text: Writ Petition No. 91 of 1957 filed by Express Newspapers Private Ltd. on June 13, 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Writ Petition No. 91 of 1957 was thereupon filed on June 13, 1957, by the Express Newspapers  Private  Ltd., against the Union of India

facts.text: Express Newspapers employ 331 working journalists out of 1570 staff; wage bill increase from Rs. 9,77,892 to Rs. 15,21,282.12 annually if Wage Board decision implemented.

issues.text: the question as to the vires of the Working Journalists Conditions of Service and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1955 (45 of 1955), hereinafter referred to as the Act and the decision of the Wage Board constituted thereunder

anchor.surface_text: raise the question as to the vires of the Working Journalists Conditions of Service and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1955 (45 of 1955), hereinafter referred to as the Act and the decision of the Wage Board constituted thereunder. As they raise common questions of law and fact they can be dealt with under one common judgment.

issues.text: the question of the maintainability of the appeals

anchor.surface_text: this Court granted the special leave in all these petitions under Art. 136 of the Constitution subject to the question of the maintainability of the appeals being open to be urged at the hearing.

issues.text: Whether the functions of the Wage Board were judicial or quasi-judicial in character

anchor.surface_text: The reply made by the respondents was that none of the fundamental rights guaranteed under Art. 19(1)(a), Art. 19(1)(g), Art. 14 and or Art. 32 were infringed by the impugned Act, that the functions of the Wage Board were not judicial or quasi-judicial

issues.text: Whether the fixation of the rates of wages was a legislative act

anchor.surface_text: that the functions of the Wage Board were not judicial or quasi-judicial in character, that the fixation of the rates of wages was a legislative act and not a judicial one

issues.text: Whether the Wage Board had the power and authority to fix the scales of wages

anchor.surface_text: that the Wage Board had the power and authority also to fix the scales of wages and to give retrospective operation to its decision

issues.text: Whether the Wage Board decision had been arrived at after taking into consideration all the criteria for fixation of wages under s. 9 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: that the decision of the Wage Board had been arrived at after taking into consideration all the criteria for fixation of wages under s. 9 of the Act and the material as well as the evidence led before it

issues.text: Whether the implementation of the decision would be beyond the capacity of the petitioners and would result in their utter collapse

anchor.surface_text: It was also contended that the implementation of the decision would be beyond the capacity of the petitioners and would result in their utter collapse.

arguments.claim: Fixation of rates of wages is legislative act not judicial

anchor.surface_text: that a considerable portion of the decisions recorded by the Wage Board were unanimous,

arguments.claim: Financial position of petitioners not such as to lead to collapse

anchor.surface_text: and that the financial position of the petitioners was not such as to lead to their collapse as a result of the impact of the provisions of the impugned Act and the decision of the Wage Board.

arguments.claim: Fixation of wages governed by normal needs, capacity to pay, nature of industry, effect on development and employment

anchor.surface_text: they stated that the fixation of rates of wages should be governed by the following criteria normal needs of a worker capacity of the industry to pay nature of the industry and effect on the development

arguments.claim: Newspaper industry is a class by itself; selling price below cost, newsprint costs varying, hazardous

anchor.surface_text: The newspaper industry was a class by itself. The selling price of its product was ordinarily below its cost of production. Further, the cost of production specially that of newsprint,

arguments.claim: Rates of wages should be at minimum level, prosperity shared via bonuses

anchor.surface_text: it was obligatory that the rates of wages or scales should be fixed at the minimum level, leaving it to the employees to share the prosperity of the units through bonuses.

arguments.claim: Increasing selling price reduces circulation and ad revenue

anchor.surface_text: It was not ordinarily easy for newspapers to increase the selling price and it had been the experience of some established newspapers that such a course, when adopted,

arguments.claim: Wage increase for journalists affects other staff sections

anchor.surface_text: In any fixation of wages of a section of employees, its effect on other sections had to be taken into consideration. Editorial employees were one section of a newspaper

arguments.claim: Capacity determined by ad revenue proportion, not gross revenue alone; region-wise wages fairer

anchor.surface_text: It was not enough to take into consideration the gross revenue of a newspaper alone but also the proportion of advertisement revenue in it. This meant that minimum salaries

arguments.claim: Majority dominated by worker needs, ignoring industry effect

anchor.surface_text: The proposals, which the majority had made, clearly showed that, according to it the dominating principle of wage fixation was the need of the worker as conceived by them,

arguments.claim: Insufficient data on industry paying capacity before Board

anchor.surface_text: The Board had not before it sufficient data needed for the proper assessment of the paying capacity of the industry.

arguments.claim: Industry condition unsatisfactory per profit/loss data

anchor.surface_text: The profit and loss statements of the daily newspaper establishments for the year 1954-55 as submitted to the Board revealed that while 43 of them had shown profits 40 had

arguments.claim: Wage scales unduly high, lead to huge burden, closures, reduced new papers, against employment and freedom

anchor.surface_text: The proposals embodied in the decision made by the majority were therefore unduly high. They would immediately throw a huge burden on many papers, a burden which would progressively grow

arguments.claim: Classification of chains/groups on total revenue unfair

anchor.surface_text: As regards chains and groups the criterion for classification adopted by the majority was unfair and unnatural.

arguments.claim: Retrospective effect aggravates troubles

anchor.surface_text: Giving of retrospective effect, would help only to aggravate the troubles of the newspaper industry which had been already called upon to devise ways and means

arguments.claim: Prevalent wages comparison limited to similar qualifications in regions, not other professions broadly

anchor.surface_text: As regards the prevalent rates of wages for comparable employments the nature of work of the working journalists in newspaper establishments could not be compared

arguments.claim: Wages fixed based on industry as whole, not particular papers; inevitable burden on some for higher journalism standards

anchor.surface_text: In fixing the rates of wages, we have based them on the condition of the newspaper industry as a whole and not on the effect which they will produce on a particular newspaper.

arguments.claim: No regret if decisions discourage entry without resources for minimum wage; not at expense of journalists

anchor.surface_text: We do not consider it a matter of regret if our decisions discourage the entry into this industry of persons without the necessary resources required for the payment

arguments.claim: Grouping chains on total revenue justified as losses borne by prosperous units; disparity in wages otherwise

anchor.surface_text: All the accounts of the constituent units in the same group or chain are merged together with the result that the losses of the weaker units are borne from the high income
